class=\"quote no-group\" data-username=\"BordomBeThyName\" data-post=\"7\" data-topic=\"473240\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"title\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"quote-controls\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cimg loading=\"lazy\" alt=\"\" width=\"24\" height=\"24\" src=\"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/48/147649_2.png\" class=\"avatar\"\u003e BordomBeThyName:\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso, you \u003cem\u003ehave\u003c/em\u003e to connect 20 motors to a robot? Why? Do they all have to do something?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003c/aside\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExtending this very relevant question:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDo they all have to do something \u003cem\u003eindependently\u003c/em\u003e?  Is it feasible to use one motor to spin two shafts, for example?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAre you unnecessarily using multiple motors to make one movement?  If you have two motors on an arm, or an elevator, or a winch, can you achieve your design goals with one?  I believe there are many times that torque and speed calculations are not done and two motors are used because someone has seen a team use two motors in the
